skill.name: when-documenting-code-use-doc-generator
skill.description: Automated comprehensive code documentation generation with API docs, README files, inline comments, and architecture diagrams
skill.summary: Automated code documentation generator for API specs, README files, inline comments, and architecture diagrams
skill.author: DNYoussef

security_audit.summary: Documentation generation skill with legitimate shell scripts for code analysis. All static findings are false positives or standard operations for documentation tools. Shell scripts use find/grep/xargs for code scanning, URLs are template references, and credential mentions are documentation only.

low_findings.title: Shell command execution in documentation scripts
low_findings.description: Shell scripts use find, grep, xargs, and git commands for code analysis. These are legitimate operations for a documentation generator that needs to scan project structure. All command arguments are hardcoded strings from the script itself, not user input.

content.value_statement: Manual documentation is time-consuming and often outdated. This skill automatically generates comprehensive API documentation, README files, inline comments, and architecture diagrams by analyzing code structure.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes code structure to identify functions, classes, and endpoints
Generates OpenAPI specifications and JSDoc/TypeDoc comments
Creates comprehensive README.md files from project metadata
Adds inline comments to undocumented code sections
Produces architecture diagrams using Graphviz or Mermaid
limitations: Does not execute code or modify runtime behavior
Requires readable source files in the project directory
Cannot verify documentation accuracy beyond syntax checking
Generated diagrams are based on static code analysis only

use_cases.title: New Project Setup
use_cases.description: Quickly generate initial documentation structure for a new project including README, API specs, and inline comments template.
use_cases.target_user: Developers starting new projects who want documentation from day one

use_cases.title: Legacy Code Documentation
use_cases.description: Add documentation to undocumented legacy codebases by analyzing existing structure and generating appropriate docstrings.
use_cases.target_user: Maintenance developers working with undocumented code

use_cases.title: API Documentation Refresh
use_cases.description: Update outdated API documentation by regenerating OpenAPI specs from current code endpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Generate API Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the documentation generator skill to create OpenAPI 3.0 documentation for this project. Look for Express.js, FastAPI, or NestJS routes and generate a complete API specification in docs/api.yml.

prompt_templates.title: Create Project README
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a comprehensive README.md for this project. Include sections for overview, installation, usage, API reference, and contributing guidelines. Extract project name, version, and dependencies from package.json or pyproject.toml.

prompt_templates.title: Add Inline Comments
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the source code and add JSDoc comments to all public functions, classes, and interfaces. Include parameter types, return types, and descriptions where documentation is missing.

prompt_templates.title: Full Documentation Suite
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate complete documentation for this project including: (1) README.md with badges and table of contents, (2) OpenAPI specification for all endpoints, (3) architecture diagram showing component relationships, (4) inline comments for undocumented code.

output_examples.input: Generate API documentation for this Express.js project
Create a README for this Node.js project
output: Created README.md with sections: Overview, Installation, Usage, API
Added badges for CI, coverage, and license
Included table of contents with anchor links

best_practices: Run documentation generation on fresh clones to avoid sensitive data exposure
Review generated documentation before committing to version control
Use the --overwrite flag cautiously as it replaces existing files
anti_patterns: Running documentation generators on production systems with live credentials
Expecting generated documentation to replace thorough code review
Ignoring documentation gaps identified by the analysis phase

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill supports JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, and other languages with detectable frameworks like Express.js, FastAPI, NestJS, and React.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my source code?
faq.answer: The skill only reads source files to analyze structure. It creates new documentation files without modifying existing source code.

faq.question: Can I customize the output format?
faq.answer: Yes, the shell scripts support options like --format for OpenAPI versions, --output for directory, and --no-badges for README generation.

faq.question: Where are documentation files generated?
faq.answer: Documentation is typically generated in a docs/ subdirectory or alongside existing files like README.md in the project root.

faq.question: Does this skill require network access?
faq.answer: The skill analyzes local files only. It references URLs in templates (like license URLs) but does not make network requests.

faq.question: What happens to existing documentation?
faq.answer: By default, existing files are backed up before modification. Use --overwrite flag to replace without backup.
